item.title: History of Cebu
item.description: The history of Cebu goes way beyond 439 years ago when the island became a province at the start of the Spanish colonization.
item.content:encoded:
--- # The Rich History of Cebu
The history of Cebu stretches back much further than 439 years ago, predating its official provincial status under Spanish colonization. Long before the Spanish arrival, Cebu was a bustling **center of trade** in what is now the southern Philippines, engaging with merchants from China, Malaysia, Japan, India, Burma, and other parts of Asia.
## Pre-Colonial Society
Before the Spaniards, Cebu boasted an organized social structure. Communities were small, typically ranging from **30 to 100 households**, grouped into units called **barangays**, largely based on kinship. Each barangay was headed by a **datu**, who served as the leader. The datu's role was multifaceted: they governed the community, settled disputes, made crucial decisions, protected their village from enemies, led them into battle, and received labor and tributes from their people. This position was both a political office and a social class, with authority derived from lineage. However, a datu's actual power depended on their wealth, the number of subjects, and their reputation for physical prowess.
Within these communities, there were also **free men called timawa** and the **olipon**. Spanish reports characterized the olipon as dependents rather than slaves, noting the absence of the violence and harshness common in European slavery.
The people of Cebu at this time were known as **pintados** due to the extensive tattooing on the men. **Lavish gold jewelry** was common, worn by both women and men as ornaments. Permanent, **townhouse-looking wooden structures** were where the datus resided, while ordinary people lived in **field cottages or *balay-balay***, which were built on stilts. Common features included a *hagdan* (house ladder), *salog* (floors) made of bamboo or wood, and an *atop* (roof) made of palm tree shingles.
## Spanish Arrival and Transformation
In **1521**, Ferdinand Magellan and his troops arrived in Cebu and were initially **warmly welcomed by Rajah Humabon's community**, who subsequently converted to Christianity. However, Magellan met a different reception on the island of Mactan, where he was **slain by the local chieftain, Lapulapu**. Cebu remained free until Manuel Lopez de Legazpi arrived in **1566**.
This marked the beginning of Cebu's transformation under Spanish rule. **Catholic churches were built**, and priests governed communities alongside civil leaders. **Watchtowers were scattered along the island** to guard against Moro raids. Economically and culturally, **fiesta celebrations were embraced**, and **new agricultural products were introduced**. Royal decrees spurred commercial and agricultural expansion, leading to the **establishment of elementary schools in every municipality**.
## Challenges and Revolutions
Between **1872 and 1896**, widespread propaganda against Spanish abuses emerged. A **sugar crisis** brought an end to the agricultural prosperity Cebu province had enjoyed, forcing sugar barons or *hacienderos* to declare bankruptcy in **1892**.
The **Philippine Revolution** against Spain began in **1898**. However, before full independence could be realized, American troops arrived, and **United States sovereignty over the Philippines was declared**. The Filipino-American War broke out on **February 7, 1900**.
The subsequent history of Cebu became intertwined with national and global events, including **World War II, the Japanese occupation, postwar reconstruction, Philippine independence, and the declaration of Martial Law**, among others.
## The Enduring Spirit of Cebuanos
Throughout all these historical events, the **valiant spirit of the Cebuanos** has remained evident. They are characterized by their principles and resilience, their dedication to hard work, and their high standards of morality and professionalism, qualities that have consistently made Cebu stand out.
item.dc:creator: CedrickPH

item.title: History of the Philippines
item.description: The history of the Philippines dates from the earliest hominin activity in the archipelago at least by 709,000 years ago.[1] Homo luzonensis, a species of archaic humans, was present on the island of Luzon[2][3] at least by 134,000 years ago.[4]
item.content:encoded:
The history of the Philippines dates from the earliest hominin activity in the archipelago at least by 709,000 years ago.[1] Homo luzonensis, a species of archaic humans, was present on the island of Luzon[2][3] at least by 134,000 years ago.[4]
The earliest known anatomically modern human was from Tabon Caves in Palawan dating about 47,000 years.[5] Negrito groups were the first inhabitants to settle in the prehistoric Philippines.[6] These were followed by Austroasiatics, Papuans, and South Asians.[7] By around 3000 BCE, seafaring Austronesians, who form the majority of the current population, migrated southward from Taiwan.[8] By 2000 BCE the archipelago was the crux of a trans-oceanic Philippine jade culture.[9]
Scholars generally believe that these ethnic and social groups eventually developed into various settlements or polities with varying degrees of economic specialization, social stratification, and political organization.[10] Some of these settlements (mostly those located on major river deltas) achieved such a scale of social complexity that some scholars believe they should be considered early states.[11] This includes the predecessors of modern-day population centers such as Manila, Tondo, Pangasinan, Cebu, Panay, Bohol, Butuan, Cotabato, Lanao, Zamboanga and Sulu[12] as well as some polities, such as Ma-i, whose possible location is either Mindoro or Laguna.[13]
These polities were influenced by Islamic, Indian, and Chinese cultures. Islam arrived from Arabia, while Indian Hindu-Buddhist[14] religion, language, culture, literature and philosophy arrived from the Indian subcontinent .[15] Some polities were Sinified tributary states allied to China. These small maritime states flourished from the 1st millennium.[16][17]
These kingdoms traded with what are now called China, India, Japan, Thailand, Vietnam, and Indonesia. The remainder of the settlements were independent barangays allied with one of the larger states. These small states alternated from being part of or being influenced by larger Asian empires like the Ming dynasty, Majapahit and Brunei or rebelling and waging war against them.[18]
The first recorded visit by Europeans is Ferdinand Magellan's expedition, which landed in Homonhon Island, now part of Guiuan, Eastern Samar, on March 17, 1521. They lost a battle against the army of Lapulapu, chief of Mactan, where Magellan was killed.[19][20][21] The Spanish Philippines began with the Pacific expansion of New Spain and the arrival of Miguel LÃ³pez de Legazpi's expedition on February 13, 1565, from Mexico. He established the first permanent settlement in Cebu.[22]
Much of the archipelago came under Spanish rule, creating the first unified political structure known as the Philippines. Spanish colonial rule saw the introduction of Christianity, the code of law, and the oldest modern university in Asia. The Philippines was ruled under the Mexico-based Viceroyalty of New Spain. After this, the colony was directly governed by Spain, following Mexico's independence.
Spanish rule ended in 1898 with Spain's defeat in the Spanishâ€“American War. The Philippines then became a territory of the United States. U.S. forces suppressed a revolution led by Emilio Aguinaldo. The United States established the Insular Government to rule the Philippines. In 1907, the elected Philippine Assembly was set up with popular elections. The U.S. promised independence in the Jones Act.[23] The Philippine Commonwealth was established in 1935, as a 10-year interim step prior to full independence. However, in 1942 during World War II, Japan occupied the Philippines. The U.S. military overpowered the Japanese in 1945. The Treaty of Manila in 1946 established the independent Philippine Republic.
item.dc:creator: Ai Lodi

item.title: E-Books vs. Print Books: Which Should You Choose?
item.description: Struggling to pick between e-books and print books? This guide breaks down the benefits and drawbacks of each to help you choose the perfect reading experience.
item.content:encoded:
E-Books vs. Print Books: Which Should You Choose? In the ongoing debate between digital and physical, books are no exception. Both e-books and print books offer unique advantages and disadvantages, making the "better" choice highly subjective and dependent on individual preferences and circumstances. Let's delve into the pros and cons of each to help you decide which format best suits your reading habits.
E-Books: The Digital Revolution E-books, read on devices like e-readers, tablets, and smartphones, have revolutionized access to literature.
Pros of E-Books:
Portability: Carry an entire library in your pocket! E-readers can store thousands of books, making them ideal for travel and commuting.
Convenience: Purchase and download books instantly, anywhere with an internet connection. No need to visit a physical store or wait for delivery.
Customization: Adjust font size, style, and line spacing to suit your visual comfort. Many e-readers also offer backlight settings for reading in low light.
Searchability: Easily search for specific words or phrases within the text, a boon for research or recalling details.
Cost-Effective (Potentially): While devices have an upfront cost, many e-books are cheaper than their print counterparts, and there are numerous free e-books available.
Environmentally Friendly (Potentially): Reduces paper consumption and the environmental impact of printing and shipping.
Interactive Features: Some e-books offer interactive elements, embedded multimedia, and hyperlinks.
Cons of E-Books:
Eye Strain: Prolonged screen time can lead to eye fatigue and discomfort for some readers, though e-ink displays are designed to mitigate this.
Battery Dependency: E-readers and devices require charging, and a dead battery means no reading.
Device Cost: The initial investment in an e-reader or tablet can be a barrier for some.
Lack of Tangibility: Many readers miss the physical sensation of holding a book, turning pages, and the smell of paper.
Digital Rights Management (DRM): Some e-books come with DRM restrictions, limiting how you can share or transfer them.
Distractions: Tablets and smartphones, while versatile, can lead to distractions from notifications and other apps.
Print Books: The Timeless Classic For centuries, print books have been the cornerstone of reading, offering a tangible and traditional experience.
Pros of Print Books:
Tactile Experience: The feel of paper, the smell of ink, and the act of turning pages provide a sensory experience that many readers cherish.
No Eye Strain (Generally): Reading from a physical page is often less strenuous on the eyes than a backlit screen.
No Battery Required: Pick up a print book anytime, anywhere, without worrying about power.
Collectibility & Aesthetics: Books can be beautiful objects, adding to home decor and offering a sense of ownership and pride in a personal library.
Resale Value & Lending: Print books can be easily lent to friends, sold, or donated.
Fewer Distractions: A print book offers a focused reading experience without the ping of notifications.
Durability (in some cases): A well-cared-for print book can last for decades, even centuries.
Cons of Print Books:
Portability Issues: Carrying multiple print books can be heavy and cumbersome, especially for travel.
Storage Space: A growing library requires significant shelf space.
Availability: May require a trip to a bookstore or library, or waiting for online delivery.
Cost: Print books often have a higher upfront cost than their e-book counterparts.
Environmental Impact: Production involves paper, ink, and transportation, contributing to environmental concerns.
Accessibility: Limited options for adjusting font size or contrast for readers with visual impairments.
The Verdict: It's Your Choice! Ultimately, the choice between e-books and print books comes down to personal preference and your individual reading lifestyle.
Choose E-Books if: You prioritize portability, convenience, customization, and enjoy digital features. You're a frequent traveler or commuter, or someone who needs to adjust text size.
Choose Print Books if: You cherish the tactile experience, prefer a screen-free reading session, enjoy collecting books, or frequently lend your reads to others.
item.dc:creator: CedrickPH

item.title: History of computing - next blog
item.description: This document outlines the fascinating evolution of computing, from ancient counting methods to the sophisticated digital world we inhabit today 123
item.content:encoded:
ðŸ’» The History of Computing This document outlines the fascinating evolution of computing, from ancient counting methods to the sophisticated digital world we inhabit today.
ðŸ•°ï¸ Early Counting and Calculation The journey began with basic methods for quantifying.
Tally Marks: Primitive techniques using notches on bones or sticks.
Abacus: An early calculating tool, originating around 2400 BCE in Mesopotamia, providing a physical means for arithmetic.
âš™ï¸ Mechanical Calculators The 17th century introduced machines capable of automated calculations.
Pascaline (1642): Invented by Blaise Pascal, designed for addition and subtraction.
Stepped Reckoner (1672): Developed by Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, extending capabilities to multiplication and division.
The 19th century was dominated by the visions of Charles Babbage, often hailed as the "Father of the Computer."
Difference Engine (1822): Conceived for tabulating polynomial functions.
Analytical Engine (1837): A groundbreaking design featuring an arithmetic logic unit, control flow, and integrated memoryâ€”a true precursor to modern general-purpose computers.
Ada Lovelace: Babbage's collaborator, credited with writing the first algorithm for the Analytical Engine, marking her as arguably the first computer programmer.
âš¡ The Dawn of Modern Computing (Electronic Era) The mid-20th century saw the transition to electronic machines.
Electromechanical & Relay-Based Systems Z3 (1941): Konrad Zuse's creation in Germany, recognized as the world's first functional program-controlled, all-electronic digital computer.
Colossus (1943): Developed in Britain during WWII for code-breaking, an early electronic digital computer.
Purely Electronic Digital Computers ENIAC (Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer) (1945): Built at the University of Pennsylvania, this was the first general-purpose electronic digital computer. It was immense, weighing 30 tons and using 18,000 vacuum tubes.
UNIVAC I (Universal Automatic Computer I) (1951): The first commercial computer in the U.S., notably predicting the 1952 presidential election outcome.
ðŸš€ The Transistor and Miniaturization The invention of the transistor in 1947 by Bell Labs marked a significant paradigm shift, enabling smaller, faster, and more energy-efficient computers.
Second Generation Computers (1950s-1960s): Characterized by the use of transistors.
Integrated Circuit (IC) (1958): Invented by Jack Kilby and Robert Noyce, integrating multiple transistors onto a single chip, leading to the third generation of computers.
Microprocessor (1971): Intel's 4004 was the first commercial microprocessor, condensing a CPU onto a single chip and paving the way for personal computing.
ðŸ–¥ï¸ The Personal Computer Revolution The 1970s and 1980s democratized computing, bringing it to homes and small businesses.
Apple I (1976) & Apple II (1977): Key contributions by Steve Wozniak and Steve Jobs in popularizing personal computers.
IBM PC (1981): IBM's entry solidified the personal computer's presence in the mainstream.
Microsoft Windows (1985): The introduction of graphical user interfaces (GUIs) significantly enhanced computer accessibility.
ðŸŒ The Internet Age and Beyond The late 20th and early 21st centuries saw unprecedented connectivity and mobility.
World Wide Web (1989): Invented by Tim Berners-Lee, this transformed global information sharing.
Smartphones and Tablets (2000s): These devices brought powerful computing into our pockets, deeply integrating technology into daily life.
Modern Trends: Ongoing advancements in Cloud Computing, Big Data, and Artificial Intelligence continue to redefine the capabilities and applications of computing.
This README provides a concise overview. For more in-depth exploration, consult specialized texts and historical archives.
item.dc:creator: ced
